security_audit.summary: This is a legitimate CI/CD verification skill. All 42 static findings are false positives: external_commands are documented examples of standard git/GitHub CLI commands; network issues are mentions of project types and example URLs; weak crypto findings are spurious keyword matches in security documentation. No malicious functionality.

content.user_title: Enforce CI verification before claiming completion
content.value_statement: This skill prevents Claude from claiming work is complete without proper CI verification. It enforces running local tests, committing code, waiting for GitHub Actions to pass, and analyzing failures before reporting success.
actual_capabilities: Run local test suites for .NET, Node.js, Python, and Go projects
Commit and push code changes to remote repositories
Monitor GitHub Actions workflows until completion
Analyze CI failures and download logs for debugging
limitations: Requires GitHub CLI installed and authenticated
Only works with GitHub Actions CI systems
Cannot fix CI failures automatically without human guidance

use_cases.title: Verify commits before push
use_cases.description: Ensure all tests pass locally and remotely before committing code changes.

use_cases.title: Enforce CI safety gates
use_cases.description: Block premature completion claims until GitHub Actions workflows confirm success.

use_cases.title: Validate CI evidence
use_cases.description: Require verifiable CI pass evidence before merging pull requests.

prompt_templates.title: Basic verification
prompt_templates.prompt: Run the verification protocol for this task. Execute local tests, commit changes, wait for CI to pass, and report success with evidence.

prompt_templates.title: Multi-workflow check
prompt_templates.prompt: Verify this PR by running local tests, pushing code, and monitoring ALL GitHub Actions workflows until they all pass. Report which workflows ran and their status.

prompt_templates.title: CI failure analysis
prompt_templates.prompt: CI failed on my last push. Download the failure logs, analyze the root cause, fix the issue, and repeat verification until all tests pass.

prompt_templates.title: Safety reminder
prompt_templates.prompt: Before you claim this task is complete, run the autonomous CI verification protocol. Do not report success until CI passes.

output_examples.input: Run the CI verification protocol for the current changes.
My PR failed CI. Help me fix it.
output: Failure log analysis: 2 test failures in src/auth.spec.ts
Issue: New authentication logic breaks existing test cases
Fix: Updated test expectations for token expiration handling
Waiting for CI to confirm fix...

best_practices: Always invoke this skill BEFORE claiming any task is complete
Wait for all CI workflows to finish, never assume success from partial results
Report CI URLs and test counts as evidence when claiming completion
anti_patterns: Claiming completion without running local tests first
Pushing code and assuming CI will pass without waiting
Reporting success based on local tests alone without CI verification

faq.question: Does this skill work with CI systems other than GitHub Actions?
faq.answer: No. This skill specifically uses GitHub CLI for GitHub Actions. Other CI systems require different tools.

faq.question: What happens if local tests pass but CI fails?
faq.answer: The skill detects the failure, downloads logs, analyzes the issue, fixes it, and repeats verification until CI passes.

faq.question: Can I skip CI verification for small changes?
faq.answer: No. The skill enforces verification for ALL changes without exceptions, regardless of change size.

faq.question: What if multiple workflows are running?
faq.answer: The skill monitors ALL workflows in .github/workflows/ and requires all to pass before claiming success.

faq.question: Does this skill modify my code?
faq.answer: No. The skill only runs tests, monitors CI, and reports findings. Code fixes require explicit user permission.

faq.question: What permissions does this skill need?
faq.answer: GitHub CLI authentication and repository access are required. No special permissions beyond standard git and gh access.
